bug.short_desc: twirssi generates warning: unescaped left brace in regex is deprecated
bug.cf_doc_type: If docs needed, set a value

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem: I haven't noticed this before and it definitely didn't happen what I started using twirssi.pl script. But, now, I get these warning every time I load twirssi script.
Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable): twirssi-2.6.3-4.fc24.noarch
How reproducible: Always since recently
Steps to Reproduce: 1. install twirssi pkg 2. load twirssi.pl in irssi
Actual results: 15:16 Unescaped left brace in regex is deprecated, passed through in regex; marked by <-- HERE in m/\${ <-- HERE |\$}/ at /home/pdestefa/.irssi/scripts/autorun/twirssi.pl line 325. 15:16 15:16 Unescaped left brace in regex is deprecated, passed through in regex; marked by <-- HERE in m/\${ <-- HERE .*?\$}/ at /home/pdestefa/.irssi/scripts/autorun/twirssi.pl line 328. 15:16 15:16 Unescaped left brace in regex is deprecated, passed through in regex; marked by <-- HERE in m/^list{ <-- HERE (.)}(?:,|$)/ at /home/pdestefa/.irssi/scripts/autorun/twirssi.pl line 3244.
Expected results: no warnings
Additional info:
I filed this bug with upstream almost a year ago but there has been no action. Based on the number of commits recently (almost none since 2014) I suspect that the project is dead.

Ah, I see. Well, that's disappointing. Is there another way to get twitter feed via IRSSI?
If not, I'll take a gander at the script and see if I can fix it.

(In reply to Paul DeStefano from comment #2) > Ah, I see. Well, that's disappointing. Is there another way to get twitter > feed via IRSSI? > > If not, I'll take a gander at the script and see if I can fix it.
I don't know of any other projects that do this. And I don't use irssi anymore, but I'd be happy to take your patch which we could apply to just the Fedora package if upstream doesn't want it.
What do you use instead of irssi now?

I think the patch was applied upstream. Would you pull?
(Still curious what you use instead of irssi, now.)
